sections.title: Introduction to FTC Robot Hardware
sections.content:
FTC robots are complex systems built from various hardware components that work together to create a functional autonomous and driver-controlled robot. Understanding these components and how they interact is essential for successful robot programming and troubleshooting.

For more details, see gm0: Hardware Map and REV Robotics: Control System.

sections.title: Core Hardware Categories
sections.subtitle: Every FTC robot includes these essential components:
items: Control Hub - The brain of the robot, running your code
Expansion Hub - Additional I/O ports for more components
DC Motors - Primary actuators for movement and mechanisms
Servos - Precise position control for arms, claws, and other mechanisms
Sensors - Eyes and ears of the robot for environmental awareness
Battery - Power source for all components
Gamepad Controllers - Human input for teleop control

sections.title: Control System Architecture
sections.content: The FTC control system is built around the Control Hub and Expansion Hub, which provide the interface between your code and the robot hardware. The FTC SDK OpMode documentation explains how your code interacts with these components.

sections.title: Control System Components
items: Control Hub: Android-based controller with built-in WiFi, USB ports, and motor/servo controllers
Expansion Hub: Additional I/O module that connects to the Control Hub via RS485
Driver Station: Android app that runs on a phone/tablet for robot control and monitoring
Robot Controller: Android app that runs on the Control Hub and executes your code

sections.title: Hardware Configuration
sections.content: The robot configuration file defines how your hardware components are connected and named. This is essential for proper communication between your code and the hardware. See gm0: Hardware Map for a step-by-step guide.

sections.title: Configuration Process
items: Configuration File: Stored on the Control Hub, defines component names and types
Component Names: Must match the names used in your code
Port Assignment: Each component is assigned to specific ports on the Control Hub
Configuration Tool: Use the Robot Controller app to create and edit configurations

sections.title: Hardware Mapping in Code
Power Management
sections.content: Proper power management is crucial for reliable robot operation. The battery provides power to all components through the Control Hub. For more, see REV Robotics: Motor Safety.

sections.title: Power Considerations
items: Battery Voltage: Monitor battery level to prevent unexpected shutdowns
Current Draw: Be aware of power consumption, especially with multiple motors
Voltage Regulation: Control Hub provides regulated power to all components
Safety Features: Built-in protection against overcurrent and overvoltage

sections.title: Battery Monitoring Example
Hardware Best Practices
sections.subtitle: Follow these guidelines for reliable hardware operation:
items: Always check battery voltage before and during operation
Use appropriate motor directions for your robot configuration
Test servos at multiple positions to ensure proper operation
Calibrate sensors and verify readings are reasonable
Secure all connections and check for loose wires
Document your hardware configuration for team reference
Have spare parts available for critical components

sections.title: Hardware Testing
sections.content: Regular testing of hardware components is essential for reliable robot operation. Create a systematic approach to testing each component. See gm0: Hardware Map for more on hardware testing.

sections.title: Testing Checklist
items: Motors: Test direction, speed control, and encoder functionality
Servos: Verify movement to all required positions
Sensors: Calibrate and test in various conditions
Connections: Check all wiring and connections
Configuration: Verify hardware mapping matches physical setup

sections.title: Hardware Familiarization
sections.description: Practice these activities to become familiar with robot hardware:
tasks: Identify all hardware components on your robot
Create a hardware configuration file for your robot
Test each motor and servo individually
